0.text:
The Ten Commandments maintain an extraordinary hold on our imaginations
even though many of them can sound – in

6.text:
the context of our own times – really rather
peculiar, with injunctions not to

10.text:
covet a neighbour’s livestock or to make sure one doesn't carve images
of god-like figures in the rocks.

16.text:
The Commandments
were responses to the specific needs of a small nomadic

21.text:
community, wandering the Sinai peninsula with
goats and sheep around

25.text:
1,200 BC. Our needs have, predictably,
 changed a bit since then.

29.text: But a place for rules remains: because we're still

33.text:
horribly prone to violence, cruelty and self-righteousness
and need regularly to be reminded of how to

39.text:
live peacefully and well with ourselves and
our neighbours.

42.text: What would it be like to try to update the commandments for our own times?

49.text: The good person is at all times

51.text:
highly aware of their flaws and committed
to becoming a better version of themselves.

56.text:
They are not insulted if people point out
their need for evolution, even when they do this rather clumsily.

62.text: A good person believes in ongoing need for moral and phsycological education..

70.text:
The good person knows that everyone is deeply damaged and a little
mad, starting with (of course) themselves.

77.text:
They are unfrightened by their own strangeness
and are committed to informing those around

81.text:
them of it in very good time, and apologising
retrospectively when they have failed to do so.

87.text:
They understand that part of their duty is
to have a ready answer to the legitimate question,

97.text:
The good person
is loyal in relationships not because they

100.text:
think their lover is perfect, but because
they know that everyone is pretty imperfect

104.text:
and rather hard to live with at close range.
They accept that the only people we can ever

109.text:
think of as normal or easy are people we don’t
yet know very well.

118.text:
The good person knows that it is impossible to be wholly understood
by anyone and accepts that things are going

124.text:
well if one is very lonely in around only
half of the key areas of one’s life.

133.text:
The good person tries hard never to assume
that other people should know what they are

137.text:
thinking of or want without them having told them very clearly and kindly. They
try to resist sulking (behaviour that stems

146.text:
from an incensed belief that others should
know why we are upset without us having  told them)

151.text:
and are committed to teaching others
about the contents of their minds.

158.text:
The good person looks at people who are behaving
badly as if they might be small children;

164.text:
that is with patience, charity and an active
search for mitigating circumstances. Though

170.text:
our societies stress the insult of being treated
as younger than one is, the good person knows

176.text:
it is the greatest privilege for anyone to
look beyond the apparently strong yet nasty

181.text:
adult to the worried, anxious and probably really rather
nice child within.

189.text:
Confronted with a piece of stupidity or evil which they could never
be guilty of, the good person doesn’t fall

194.text:
into self-righteousness. They swiftly remember
all the many stupid and evil things they have

200.text:
at other points, over different things, been
guilty of. They don’t lose sight of how

205.text:
much they overall stand in need of the charity
and forgiveness of others.

213.text:
The good person is committed to searching for the funny side
of people who might appear merely desperately

218.text:
irritating. They look at others like characters
in a comedy rather than a tragedy. They know

224.text:
that the greatest achievement is to be able
to move from seeing someone as an ‘idiot’

228.text:
to considering them as that most privileged
of beings: a ‘loveable idiot.’

236.text:
The good person is a firm believer in restraint
and in not immediately saying certain things

241.text:
that are on their minds. They hold that being
fully oneself entails a level

246.text:
of melodrama and rage that one should spare
any human one cares about.

253.text:
The good person knows that the best protection against impatience
and paranoia is a little gently-worn pessimism.

259.text:
They budget for disappointment far ahead of
time. They don’t cry constantly only because

265.text:
they have understood that the whole of existence
is – in many ways – worthy of tears. Their

271.text:
constant awareness of the possibility of death
and catastrophe makes them especially appreciative

276.text:
of small things that happen to go well. They
relish flowers, balmy skies and so-called

282.text:
‘boring days’ when everyone manages to
go to bed relatively content and at peace.
